text.title: Peggy J. Kleinplatz
text.head: Peggy J. Kleinplatz
text.p: Peggy Joy Kleinplatz is a Canadian clinical professor, psychologist, and sexologist whose work often concerns optimal sexuality, opposition to the medicalization of human sexuality, and outreach to marginalized groups.[1][2]
text.head: Education
text.p: Peggy Joy Kleinplatz graduated from University of Ottawa with a B.A. (Honours) in Psychology in 1981 and Ph.D. in 1987.[3] Her dissertation was titled The impact of gender-role identity, conformity and choice on women's self-esteem, lifestyle satisfaction and conflict. Kleinplatz's doctoral advisor was Michael McCarrey.[4]
text.head: Career
text.p: Kleinplatz is a full Professor of Medicine and Clinical Professor of Psychology at the University of Ottawa.[3] Kleinplatz is a certified clinical psychologist and sex therapist and has taught human sexuality for over 20 years at the University of Ottawa.[5] She is an Adjunct Research Professor at Carleton University.[6] She has also held the Chair of Ethics and the Chair of Certifications for the American Association of Sexuality Educators, Counsellors and Therapists (AASECT).[7]

Kleinplatz and physician Charles Allen Moser argue that paraphilias should be removed from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).[8] Kleinplatz wrote, "[T]he DSM criteria for diagnosis of unusual sexual interests as pathological rests on a series of unproven and more importantly, untested assumptions."[9] Therapists who focus on "functional" versus "dysfunctional" sex, have an approach, she writes that "is, at best, limiting and constraining and, at worst, dehumanising and risks exacerbating rather than alleviating suffering."[10] Kleinplatz criticized sex therapy as being "too performance oriented," and not focusing enough on desire.[11] Her work has been to focus more on ways that partners can please one another by learning to listen to what their partners want.[12][13] Kleinplatz has shown that "great sex flourishes in relationships that deepen with maturity," according to the Globe and Mail.[14] She has also criticized the concepts premenstrual dysphoric disorder[15] and dyspareunia as medicalizing women's bodies.[16]

Her book, New Directions in Sex Therapy: Innovations and Alternatives (2001), was considered by the Journal of Sex & Marital Therapy to be an important challenge to current models of sex therapy.[17] The book is also a feminist critique of sex therapy and describes modern issues facing the practice.[18] The second edition came out in 2012 and it was updated and expanded.[19] New Directions in Sex Therapy (2nd edition) was a co-winner for an AASECT award in 2013.[7] Her book, Sadomasochism:Powerful Pleasures (2006), examines fifteen in-depth cases of different types of couples who practices sadomasochism.[20]
text.head: Awards and honors
text.p: Kleinplatz was awarded the Prix d'excellence at University of Ottawa.[3]
